Fig. 1 Representative TEM and HRTEM images of (A1, A2) TiO2{100}, (B1, B2) TiO2{101}, (C1, C2) TiO2{001}, (D1, D2) FeOx/TiO2{100}, (E1, E2) FeOx/TiO2{101}, and (F1, F2) FeOx/TiO2{001} catalysts. Insets in Fig. 1A1–C1 show corresponding models. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Representative TEM and HRTEM images of (A1, A2) Ir/TiO2{100}, (B1, B2) Ir/TiO2{101}, (C1, C2) Ir/TiO2{001}, (D1, D2) Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100}, (E1, E2) Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101}, and (F1, F2) Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (A) Ir particle shape analysis: schematic model of the particle shape analysis; The frequencies of the Ir particle diameter ratios (D1/D2) of (B1) Ir/TiO2{100}, (B2) Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100}, (C1) Ir/TiO2{101}, (C2) Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101}, (D1) Ir/TiO2{001}, and (D2) Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalysts. Fig 3 Fig. 4 XRD patterns of (A) TiO2{100}, FeOx/TiO2{100}, Ir/TiO2{100}, and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100}, (B) TiO2{101}, FeOx/TiO2{101}, Ir/TiO2{101}, and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101}, and (C) TiO2{001}, FeOx/TiO2{001}, Ir/TiO2{001}, and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalysts. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Ti 2p and O 1s XPS spectra of (A1 and A2) TiO2{100}, FeOx/TiO2{100}, Ir/TiO2{100}, and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100}, (B1 and B2) TiO2{101}, FeOx/TiO2{101}, Ir/TiO2{101}, and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101}, and (C1 and C2) TiO2{001}, FeOx/TiO2{001}, Ir/TiO2{001}, and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalysts. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Fe 2p XPS spectra of various (A1) FeOx/TiO2 and (B1) Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts; Ir 4f XPS spectra of various (A2) Ir/TiO2 and (B2) Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts. Fig 6 Fig. 7 In situ DRIFTS of CO chemisorption at room temperature over various (A) Ir/TiO2 and (B) Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts. Fig 7 Fig. 8 H2-TPR profiles of unreduced (A) TiO2{100}, FeOx/TiO2{100}, Ir/TiO2{100}, and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100}, (B) TiO2{101}, FeOx/TiO2{101}, Ir/TiO2{101}, and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101}, and (C) TiO2{001}, FeOx/TiO2{001}, Ir/TiO2{001}, and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalysts. Fig 8 Fig. 9 (A) CO conversion, (B) O2 selectivity, and (C) reaction rate of CO (molCO molIr -1 h-1) of various Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts in CO-PROX reaction. Fig 9 Fig. 10 In situ time-resolved DRIFTS spectra of first 1% CO/N2, then 1% CO/1% O2/N2, and finally 1% CO/1% O2/50% H2/N2 stepwise reaction atmospheres at 50 oC over (A) Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100}, (B) Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101}, and (C) Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalysts. Tailoring Ir-FeOx interactions and catalytic performance in preferential oxidation of CO in H2 via the morphology engineering of anatase TiO2 over Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts Yang Wen Methodology a 1 Lebing Xia Methodology a 1 Jing Zhang Methodology a 1 Cen Tang Validation a Aiping Jia Validation a Yu Bai Validation b Zhenhua Zhang Visualization Supervision Funding acquisition Project administration Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Zhejiang Key Laboratory for Reactive Chemistry on Solid Surfaces, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, People's Republic of China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials Zhejiang Key Laboratory for Reactive Chemistry on Solid Surfaces Institute of Physical Chemistry Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 People's Republic of China aKey Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Zhejiang Key Laboratory for Reactive Chemistry on Solid Surfaces, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, People's Republic of China b Experimental Center of Engineering and Material Sciences, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, People's Republic of China Experimental Center of Engineering and Material Sciences University of Science and Technology of China Hefei 230026 People's Republic of China bExperimental Center of Engineering and Material Sciences, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, People's Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts with both Ir and Fe contents of ∼1% wt. employing anatase TiO2 nanocrystals predominantly exposing either {100}, {101}, or {001} facets as the support were prepared and a comprehensive study was conducted on their interactions in pairs that are strongly dependent on the TiO2 morphology. The strongest FeOx-TiO2 interactions occurred over TiO2{001} support while TiO2{101} support contributes to the strongest Ir-TiO2 and Ir-FeOx interactions. Catalytic performance of the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts in preferential oxidation of CO in H2 is not only affected by the CO reactivity, but also determined by the Ir-FeOx interfaces. Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst exhibits the highest CO conversion and best O2 selectivity over the three Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts, which could be ascribed to stronger Ir-FeOx interactions that contribute to the enhancement of a H-spillover effect and subsequently facilitate the transformation of surface carbonaceous intermediates into CO2. These results add the versatility of the morphology engineering strategy in tailoring the structures and catalytic performance of oxide-based catalysts, and broaden the concept of morphology-dependent catalysis of oxide-based nanocrystal catalysts. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Morphology engineering Ir-FeOx interactions H-spillover effect CO-PROX Ir-FeOx/TiO2 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Oxides are widely used as catalysts and catalyst supports in heterogeneous catalysis. It is generally recognized that the catalytic performance of oxide catalysts is determined by their surface composition and structure that affect the adsorption and activation of reactants, the inter-reaction of adsorbed reactants to form desired products, and the desorption of adsorbed products [1–3]. According to the Wulff's rule [4], the morphology of an oxide nanocrystal (NC) determines the exposed crystal planes that affect the surface composition and structure, which generates the concept of morphology-dependent catalysis of uniform oxide NCs [5–11]. In addition, the morphology of oxides as the support has been demonstrated to strongly affect the structures and catalytic performance of the resulting oxide-involved catalysts [12–16]. It has therefore become a new approach employing the morphology engineering strategy of oxides as the support to tailor structures and optimize performance in catalysis involving oxide-based catalysts. As one of the most important oxides, TiO2 has been widely used as catalyst and catalyst support in heterogeneous catalysis [17–19]. Previously, uniform TiO2 NCs with different morphologies that predominantly expose one or two types of crystal planes have been successfully prepared [12,15,16,20–22]. The TiO2-supported single component catalysts employing these TiO2 NCs have also been demonstrated to strongly affect the active component-TiO2 interfaces and their interactions, and the catalytic performance in a variety of catalytic reactions [12,16,23–27]. However, it is still lacking a comprehensive study of the TiO2 morphology on tuning the structures and catalytic performance of TiO2 supported metal-oxide bi-component catalysts, which could be an intriguing subject. The preferential oxidation of CO in H2 (CO-PROX) is regarded as the promising on-board approach to remove the residual CO in H2-rich atmospheres as this process can be applied to the purification of H2 prior to the applications of proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) in transportation, portable electric devices, and residential cogeneration [28,29]. It was previously reported that the Ir-FeOx catalysts are highly active for CO-PROX reaction that is even comparable to that of Pt-group catalysts [30]. Experimental evidences revealed that the catalytic properties of Ir-FeOx catalysts are determined by the structure of Ir-FeOx interfaces [30–32]. For instance, the Ir-FeOx/SiO2 catalyst prepared by a co-impregnation method exhibits the optimal properties in the CO-PROX reaction, which could be ascribed to the high dispersions of both Ir and FeOx species on the SiO2 support that results in a dual-active sites noncompetitive Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism with CO adsorbed on Ir sites and O2 activated on FeOx sites, respectively [32]. Moreover, the atomic layer deposition (ALD) technique was used to tailor the Ir-FeOx interfaces where a 1.5 nm Ir/SiO2 sample with two cycles of FeOx overcoating exhibits the optimal catalytic performance in the CO-PROX reaction [30]. In spite of the Ir-FeOx interfaces are widely recognized as the active sites in CO-PROX reaction, it is difficult to obtain the precise control of Ir-FeOx interfaces via the conventional wet-chemistry methods. Therefore, the morphology engineering strategy of the oxide support may be a potential strategy to address this issue. Herein, various Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts were prepared via an incipient wetness co-impregnation method. Strong morphology effect of the TiO2 support was observed in the structure, interactions in pairs, and catalytic performance of the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts. It was found that the morphology of the TiO2 support not only affects the Ir-TiO2 and FeOx-TiO2 interactions, but also determines the supported Ir-FeOx interactions. The Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst exhibits the strongest Ir-FeOx interactions and can enhance the H-spillover effect and subsequently facilitate the transformation of surface carbonaceous intermediates into CO2, responsible for its best catalytic performance in CO-PROX reaction. These results broaden the applications of the morphology engineering strategy of oxide supports in tuning structures and catalytic performance of oxide-based catalysts. 2 Experimental section All the chemicals and reagents, including TiCl4, NH4Cl, (NH4)2SO4, Ti(OBu)4, HCl, NaOH, NH3.H2O, HF, iPrOH, Fe(NO3)3 · 9H2O, H2IrCl6 and absolute ethanol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. and used without further purification. Reaction gasses, including 5% H2/N2, 2% CO/2% O2/N2, H2 (> 99.999%), N2 (> 99.999%), and 10% CO/N2 were purchased from Nanjing Shangyuan Industrial Factory and used without further purification. Deionized water with a resistivity of more than 18.5 MΩ was used. 2.1 Catalyst preparations Preparations of anatase TiO2{100} and TiO2{101} NCs: Anatase TiO2{100} and TiO2{101} NCs were prepared according to the procedure reported by Liu et al. [20]. Typically, 6.6 mL of TiCl4 salt solution was added dropwise into HCl aqueous solution (0.4 mol/L, 20 mL) at 0 °C. After stirring for 30 min, the mixture solution was added dropwise into 50 mL of NH3 aqueous solution (5.5 wt.%) at room temperature (RT). Next, the pH value was adjusted to 6, 7 using NH3 aqueous solution (4 wt.%), after which the system was stirred at RT for another 2 h. The acquired precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water until no residual Cl– was detected by AgNO3 aqueous solution. The solid was finally dried at 70 °C for 12 h to obtain a Ti(OH)4 white powder. In the preparation of TiO2{100} NCs, 2 g of the as-prepared Ti(OH)4 and 0.5 g of (NH4)2SO4 were dispersed in a mixture containing 15 mL of deionized water and 15 mL of iPrOH under continuous stirring at RT. Next, the suspension was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL) and kept at 180 °C for 24 h. The acquired white precipitate was collected and washed with deionized water repeatedly. The preparation process of the TiO2{101} NCs is similar to that of TiO2{100} NCs except the 0.5 g of (NH4)2SO4 is replaced by 0.2 g of NH4Cl in the initial suspension. Preparation of anatase TiO2{001} NCs: Anatase TiO2{001} NCs were prepared according to the procedure reported by Han et al. [21]. Typically, 25 mL of Ti(OBu)4 and 3 mL of HF (40 wt.%) were mixed under stirring at RT. The mixture was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL) and kept at 180 °C for 24 h. Afterwards, the acquired white precipitate was collected by centrifugation, washed repeatedly with absolute ethanol and deionized water for several times, and finally dried at 70 °C for 24 h. The solid powder was subsequently dispersed in a NaOH aqueous solution (700 mL,1 mol/L) and stirred at RT for 24 h. Finally, the solid was further centrifuged and washed repeatedly with deionized water until the pH value reaching 7, 8. Preperations of the Ir/TiO2, FeOx/TiO2 and Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts: The Ir/TiO2 or FeOx/TiO2 catalysts were prepared via a conventional incipient wetness impregnation method. Typically, 0.3 g of as-prepared TiO2 NCs was adequately impregnated with 500 μL of aqueous solution containing the calculated amounts of H2IrCl6 or Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (both nominal Ir or Fe contents was 1 wt.%). The resulting sample was sequentially dried in the dryer oven at RT for 24 h, calcined at 450 °C for 2 h, and reduced by 5% H2/N2 with a flow rate of 30 mL/min at 300 °C for 2 h to prepare the Ir/TiO2 or FeOx/TiO2 catalysts that were subsequently stored in a vacuum oven. Similarly, preparation of the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts employed a conventional incipient wetness co-impregnation method. The preparation process is similar to that of the Ir/TiO2 or FeOx/TiO2 catalysts except the initial aqueous solution containing a mixture of H2IrCl6 and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (both nominal Ir and Fe contents were 1 wt.%). 2.2 Catalyst characterizations Power X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with a nickel-filtered Cu Kα (λ = 0.15418 nm) radiation source operated with an operation current of 50 mA and an operation voltage of 40 kV. The contents of Ir and Fe in each catalyst including the Ir/TiO2, FeOx/TiO2 and Ir-FeOx/TiO2 were determined by an Optima 7300DV inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were conducted on an ESCALAB 250Xi instrument with a monochromatized Al Kα (hν = 1486.7 eV) excitation source. The likely charging of sample was corrected by setting the binding energy of the adventitious carbon (C 1s) to 284.8 eV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were recorded on a JEOL JEM-2100F instrument. The Ir particle size and shape analyses over the Ir/TiO2 and Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts were quantified on more than 200 particles in the enlarged TEM images. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was conducted on a gas chromatograph with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Typically, 30 mg of as-prepared sample was loaded in a quartz microreactor and then heated at a rate of 10 °C min–1 up to 800 °C under a 5% H2/N2 atmosphere with a flow rate of 30 mL min–1. The H2 consumption was recorded by the thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transformed spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were performed on a Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with an MCT/A detector and an in situ DRIFTS reaction cell in series mode with 256 scans and a resolution of 4 cm–1. Prior to measurement, 50 mg of as-prepared unreduced sample was in situ treated in 5% H2/N2 with a flow rate of 30 mL min–1 at 300 °C for 2 h and then purged with highly pure N2 at 300 °C for another 0.5 h before cooling down to RT. For in situ DRIFTS of CO chemisorption, the acquired Ir/TiO2 or Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts were purged in N2 with a flow rate of 30 mL min–1 at RT for 0.5 h, whose spectra was recorded as the background spectra. Afterwards, the gas was transferred to 10% CO/N2 with a flow rate of 30 mL min–1 for 30 min till saturation, whose spectra was recorded. For the in situ DRIFTS spectra in the stepwise reactions, the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalyst purged in N2 atmosphere with a flow rate of 30 mL min–1 at 50 °C was recorded as the background spectra. Subsequently, 1% CO/N2 was introduced with a flow rate of 40 mL min–1 for 30 min till the steady state and the time-resolved spectrum was recorded. Next, 1% O2 was introduced at the presence of 1% CO/N2 (1% CO/1% O2/N2) with a total flow rate of 40 mL min–1. The surface reaction was proceeded for 30 min till the steady state and the time-resolved spectrum was recorded. Finally, 50% H2 was introduced with a mixed gas of 1% CO/1% O2/50% H2/N2 at a total flow rate of 40 mL min–1. The time-resolved spectrum was recorded after surface reaction for 30 min. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluations The CO-PROX reaction was conducted in a fixed bed reactor containing 50 mg of as-prepared unreduced catalysts diluted with 50 mg of SiO2. Prior to measurement, the sample was in situ reduced by 5% H2/N2 with a flow rate of 30 mL min–1 at 300 °C for 2 h and then cooled down to RT naturally. The reaction gas consisting 1% CO, 1% O2 and 50% H2 balanced with N2 was fed at a flow rate of 30 mL min–1. The sample was heated to the desired temperature at a heating rate of 2 °C min–1 and then kept for 35 min until the reaction reached a steady state. The compositions of the effluent gas were analyzed by an on-line gas chromatography equipped with a TCD detector (FULI 9790 Plus). The CO conversion (Eq. (1)) and O2 selectivity (Eq. (2)) were calculated by the following equations. (1) C O C o n v . = ( C O i n l e t − − C O o u t l e t ) / C O i n l e t × 100 (2) O 2 , s e l e c t . = C O 2 / 2 / ( O 2 , i n l e t − − O 2 , o u t l e t ) × 100 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 A1–C1 show representative TEM images of anatase TiO2 NCs with different morphologies prepared via well-established procedures [12,24,25]. Lattice fringes of 0.19, 0.24 and 0.35 nm in the HRTEM images (Fig. 1A2–C2) correspond to the spacing of anatase TiO2{200}, TiO2{004} and TiO2{101} (JCPDS card No. 21-1272) crystal planes, respectively. Agreeing with previously reported results [12,24], the three anatase TiO2 NCs predominantly expose either {100}, {101}, or {001} crystal planes, respectively, on which the morphologies are quite uniform with the percentage of dominantly exposed facets in each TiO2 NCs to be around 80–100% (Figs. S1–S3). The measured BET surface areas are very close for three TiO2 NCs with a value of around 100 m2 g–1. The Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts with nominal Ir and Fe contents of 1% were prepared via an incipient wetness co-impregnation method, followed by the calcination in a muffle furnace at 450 °C for 2 h and the reduction in 5% H2/N2 at 300 °C for 2 h. As comparisons, the corresponding Ir/TiO2 catalyst with a nominal Ir content of 1% and FeOx/TiO2 catalyst with a nominal Fe content of 1% were prepared by the analogous approach to that of the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts. As measured by ICP-AES (Table 1 ), the actual Ir and/or Fe contents in each catalyst are very close to the amount of added precursors during preparation. Subsequently, their microscopic structural characterizations were conducted systematically. For the FeOx/TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 1 D–F), the original TiO2 morphologies are maintained well, indicating that the structures of TiO2 support remain intact during the preparation process of the FeOx/TiO2 catalysts. The FeOx nanoparticles (NPs) are not observed in the TEM images (Fig. 1D1–F1) but easily identified in the HRTEM images (labeled by blue circles in Fig. 1D2–F2). This could be due to the similar contrast of FeOx and TiO2 under the TEM mode. The additional lattice fringe of 0.24/0.25 nm observed in the HRTEM images (Fig. 1D2–F2) corresponds to the spacing of Fe3O4{311} crystal plane (JCPDS card No. 26-1136), demonstrating that the FeOx species dominantly exists in Fe3O4 form. Fig. 2 shows the TEM and HRTEM images of various Ir/TiO2 and Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts. Similar to the FeOx/TiO2 catalysts, the original TiO2 morphologies are not modified after Ir (Fig. 2A1–C1) or Ir-FeOx (Fig. 2D1–F1) loading, demonstrating the highly stable structures of the TiO2 supports. In the enlarged TEM images (Fig. S4), the fine Ir NPs were clearly observed with the average Ir particle sizes similarly for the Ir/TiO2 catalysts (ca. 1.5 nm, insets in Fig. 2A1–C1) but slightly different for the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts (insets in Fig. 2D1–F1), which could be ascribed to the discrepancy between the Ir-TiO2 interactions and the Ir-FeOx interactions varying with the TiO2 morphology. The corresponding HRTEM images of the Ir/TiO2 catalysts reveal a lattice fringe of 0.22 nm (labeled by yellow circles in Fig. 2A2–C2), which matches well with the spacing of Ir{111} crystal plane (JCPDS card No. 46-1044). This indicates the formation of metallic Ir species on these catalysts. Notably, both the lattice fringes arising from metallic Ir and Fe3O4 species can be identified to be closely in contact over the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 2D2–F2), which provides a direct evidence for the formation of Ir-FeO2 interface. The Ir particle shape was further analyzed on basis of the two-dimensional projection in the TEM image of an individual Ir particle (Fig. S4), which determines the ratio between the short diameter (D1) and the long diameter (D2), as shown the models in Fig. 3 A. To our surprise, the D1/D2 ratios over all the Ir/TiO2 and the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts are strongly dependent on the TiO2 morphology (Fig. 3B1–D1 and B2–D2). The fractions of Ir particles with D1/D2 ratios no more than 0.8 respectively are ca. 69% and ca. 78% for the Ir/TiO2{101} and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalysts, which are prominently higher than those of Ir&Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} (56 and 63%) and Ir&Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} (40 and 39%) catalysts. This indicates more amount of flat Ir NPs formed on the Ir/TiO2{101} and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalysts. Previous studies demonstrated that the formation of flat metal NPs was associated with the metal-support interactions [12,23]. It therefore suggests that the Ir-TiO2 interactions are relatively stronger over the Ir/TiO2{101} catalyst than over the Ir/TiO2{100} and Ir/TiO2{001} catalysts. As well, the Ir-FeOx interactions over Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst are also relatively stronger than those over Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalyst. Afterwards, spectroscopic characterizations were conducted. In the XRD patterns (Fig. 4 ), all the pristine TiO2 and TiO2-suppored catalysts display the exclusive reflections characteristic for anatase TiO2 without the appearances of Ir- and/or FeOx-associated diffraction patterns. This demonstrates the formations of highly dispersed Ir and/or FeOx species in these catalysts, consistent with their fine particles observed in the TEM/HRTEM images (Figs. 1 D–F and 2). The surface compositions of the TiO2, Ir/TiO2, FeOx/TiO2, and Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts were studied by XPS spectroscopy. In the Ti 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 5 A1–C1), all catalysts exhibit one symmetric component with Ti 2p3/2 binding energy of 458.7 eV, typically arising from the Ti(IV) feature. No visible change of the Ti binding energy after Ir and/or FeOx loading was observed, which further demonstrates that the preparation process seldom affects the surface structure of the TiO2 support. The corresponding O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 5A2–C2 and Table S1) are significantly different. Two types of O 1s components with binding energies at 529.2–529.9 and 330.7–332.8 eV were observed for all catalysts, which could be ascribed to surface lattice oxygen (Olattice) and oxygenate (Ooxygenate) species, respectively [24]. Compared to the fresh TiO2 NCs, the O 1s binding energy does not vary obviously for the FeOx/TiO2 catalysts while that after the Ir loadings shifts to lower values. A ca. 0.7 eV decline of the binding energy of Olattice species for the Ir/TiO2 and Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts compared to that of the bare TiO2 NCs suggests a charge transfer from Ir to O atoms that results in the increase of the valence electron density and subsequently the enhancement of the shielding effect in the outer electron to finally weaken the O 1s binding energy. Moreover, the percentages of Ooxygenate species in the TiO2-supported Ir and Ir-FeOx catalysts always present an order of TiO2{101} > TiO2{100} > TiO2{001}, while that in the TiO2-supported FeOx catalysts follows an order of TiO2{101} > TiO2{001} > TiO2{100} (Table 1). This indicates that the oxygenate species such as carbonaceous species and hydroxyl groups are easily produced on the TiO2{101} support. Information on the electronic properties of the Fe species in the FeOx/TiO2 and Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts was acquired from the deconvoluted Fe 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 6 A1 and B1, Table S2). Two iron features with the Fe 2p3/2 binding energies at 709.4 and 711.4 eV together with the satellite peaks of Fe3+ species located at ca. 715.0 eV appear for all Fe-containing catalysts, which can be ascribed to Fe2+ and Fe3+ species, respectively. For the FeOx/TiO2 catalysts, the percentage of Fe2+ species varies with the TiO2 morphology, following the order of FeOx/TiO2{001} > FeOx/TiO2{100} > FeOx/TiO2{101} (Table 1). The appearance of Fe2+ could be associated with the FeOx-TiO2 interactions involving a charge transfer from TiO2 to FeOx. This suggests stronger FeOx-TiO2 interactions over FeOx/TiO2{001} catalyst than those over FeOx/TiO2{100} and FeOx/TiO2{101} catalysts. After addition of the Ir species, the percentage of Fe2+ species variation with the TiO2 morphology over the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts presents a reverse order to that over the FeOx/TiO2 catalysts, among which the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst exhibits the highest percentage of Fe2+ species (Table 1). The change of Fe2+ species should arise from the formation of Ir-FeOx interfaces that generate the Ir-FeOx interactions involving a charge transfer from Ir to FeOx. Therefore, compared to those of corresponding FeOx/TiO2 catalysts, the percentage of Fe2+ species increases on Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} catalysts but declines on Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalyst. It indicates that relatively stronger Ir-FeOx interactions appear on the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} catalysts, while the interactions on the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalyst is the weakest. The electronic properties of the Ir species in the Ir/TiO2 and Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts were evaluated by XPS and in situ DRIFTS of CO chemisorption. The Ir 4f XPS overlapped with Ti 3s XPS spectra (Fig. 6A2 and B2, Table S3). The deconvoluted spectra of all Ir-containing catalysts show two symmetric iridium components with Ir 4f7/2 binding energies of 60.3 and 62.3 eV, typically arising from Ir0 and Irδ+ features, respectively. On the basis of the deconvoluted XPS spectra, the percentage of Irδ+ species in the Ir/TiO2 catalysts can be calculated, showing an order of Ir/TiO2{101} > Ir/TiO2{100} > Ir/TiO2{001} (Table 1). Similarly, the observed Irδ+ species in the Ir/TiO2 catalysts should be related to the Ir-TiO2 interactions that affect the interfacial charge transfer from Ir to TiO2. It, therefore, indicates that the titania morphology dependence of the Ir-TiO2 interactions should be opposite to that of the FeOx-TiO2 interactions, similar to previously reported results of Cu or Cu2O supported on anatase TiO2 NCs with different morphologies [24]. For the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts, the addition of FeOx generates the Ir-FeOx interfaces that result in an increase of the Irδ+ percentage compared to the corresponding Ir/TiO2 catalysts, in particular on the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} catalysts (Table 1). This, on the one hand, matches well with the change of Fe2+ species (Fig. 6A1 and B1), on the other hand, it further demonstrates that the Ir-FeOx interactions in the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts follow the order of Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} > Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} > Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001}. In the in situ DRIFTS spectra of CO chemisorption (Fig. 7 ), four CO adsorption peaks centered at ca. 2062–2073, 2030–2045, 1995–2005, and 1965–1975 cm–1, respectively denoted as α1, β1, α2, and β2, were observed on both the Ir/TiO2 and the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts. These can be ascribed to CO chemisorbed on the iridium sites in different types due to no CO adsorption features appearing on FeOx and/or TiO2 at RT. Typically, the β1 and β2 peaks are assigned to linear and bridged CO bonded to the Ir0 sites (L-CO and B-CO) [33–36], respectively, whereas the α1 and α2 peaks arise from gem‑dicarbonyl CO adsorbed on the Irδ+ sites (G-CO) in two modes of the symmetric (α1) and antisymmetric (α2) dicarbonyl vibrations [33,36–38]. The surface percentages of Ir0 and Irδ+ sites were calculated by the deconvoluted CO adsorption signals (Table S4). As shown in Table 1, the percentages of Irδ+ sites over all Ir-containing catalysts are prominently higher than the corresponding results calculated on basis of the deconvoluted Ir 4f XPS spectra (Fig. 6A2 and B2). This could be due to that the true surface is detected by in situ DRIFTS of CO chemisorption while the XPS spectroscopy can detect the subsurface within a depth of ca. 5 nm. In agreement with the XPS results, the percentages of Irδ+ species in both the Ir/TiO2 and the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts follow the order of TiO2{101} > TiO2{100} > TiO2{001}. Meanwhile, compared to the corresponding Ir/TiO2 catalysts, the increased Irδ+ percentage as the formation of Ir-FeOx interfaces is more prominent over Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} catalysts than that over Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalyst. These results further confirm the relatively stronger Ir-FeOx interactions appearing on Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} catalysts. Subsequently, the reduction properties of unreduced TiO2, Ir/TiO2, FeOx/TiO2, and Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts were investigated by H2-TPR experiments. As shown in Fig. 8 , for various bare TiO2 NCs (Fig. 8, black lines), two weak reduction peaks appearing above 500 °C definitely belong to the reduction features of TiO2. Interestingly, the reduction peaks of TiO2{101} and TiO2{100} NCs are similar and finished prior to 750 °C while those of TiO2{001} NCs are obviously higher with the reduction temperatures located at ca. 648 and 778 °C. This could be related to morphology-dependent surface structures of TiO2 NCs and subsequent ability to activate H2, consistent with previous literature [27,39]. After the addition of FeOx (Fig. 8, red lines), the reduction peaks of TiO2 shift to low temperature for all unreduced FeOx/TiO2 catalysts, indicating the formations of FeOx-TiO2 interfaces that can promote the reduction of TiO2 support [40]. It is, besides the reduction features of TiO2, noteworthy that the reducibility of FeOx species varies with the TiO2 morphology. The reduction peak of FeOx species is located at ca. 740 °C for unreduced FeOx/TiO2{100} and FeOx/TiO2{101} catalysts, which is strikingly higher than that of unreduced FeOx/TiO2{001} catalyst with the reduction peaks located at ca. 514 and 583 °C overlapped with the reduction of TiO2. This may be ascribed to stronger FeOx-TiO2 interactions observed on FeOx/TiO2{001} catalyst that contributes to the enhanced reducibility of FeOx species. Beneficial from the H-spillover effect over Ir-TiO2 interfaces, the reduction of the TiO2 support shifts to lower temperature over unreduced Ir/TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 8, blue lines) [30,41]. Four reduction peaks below 500 °C were observed to be successively ascribed to the reductions of large IrOx NPs, well-dispersed IrOx species interacting strongly with the support, and the oxygen species of TiO2 facilitated by the H-spillover effect as the rise of reduction temperature [42,43]. The reduction feature of large IrOx NPs is similar and located at ca. 120–130 °C over the three unreduced Ir/TiO2 catalysts, suggesting that their structures of large IrOx NPs are not significantly different. However, the reductions of well-dispersed IrOx species interacting strongly with the support (ca. 158 °C) and the oxygen species of TiO2 facilitated by the H-spillover effect (ca. 305 and 350 °C) over the unreduced Ir/TiO2{101} and Ir/TiO2{100} catalysts are relatively easier than those over the unreduced Ir/TiO2{001} catalyst (ca. 224 oC; ca. 322 and 454 °C), matching well with stronger Ir-TiO2 interactions on Ir/TiO2{101} and Ir/TiO2{100} catalysts than on Ir/TiO2{001} catalyst. As such, an additional reduction peak located at ca. 650 °C was only observed on unreduced Ir/TiO2{101} and Ir/TiO2{100} catalysts but not on unreduced Ir/TiO2{001} catalyst, which likely arises from stronger Ir-TiO2 interactions over the former two to contribute to the enhancement of H-spillover effect and result in the reduction of partial bulk TiO2. For the unreduced Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 8, green lines), the reduction feature is very similar to that of unreduced Ir/TiO2 catalysts except the prominent intensity increase of the reduction peak previously assigned to the reduction of well-dispersed IrOx species interacting strongly with the support. Due to the addition of FeOx into the unreduced Ir/TiO2 catalysts, the enhanced intensity over the unreduced Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts should arise from the reduction of the FeOx species facilitated by the H-spillover effect. It is noteworthy that the reduction temperature of the FeOx species over the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst (ca. 169 °C) is slightly lower than that over the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} catalyst (ca. 172 °C) but observably lower than that over the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalyst (ca. 224 °C). This suggests a better H-spillover effect appearing on the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst that is beneficial from its stronger Ir-FeOx interactions. The catalytic performance of the FeOx/TiO2, Ir/TiO2, and Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts was evaluated in the CO-PROX reaction. The CO and O2 conversions were only observed on Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts. Since the FeOx/TiO2 and Ir/TiO2 catalysts are inactive under the chosen reaction conditions, the catalytic behaviors of the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts should arise from the Ir-FeOx interfaces, consistent with previous literature [30–32]. Fig. 9 shows the catalytic performance of the three Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts in the CO-PROX reaction. The results reveal that both the CO conversion (Fig. 9A) and the O2 selectivity (Fig. 9B) are strongly dependent on the TiO2 morphology. Under the same reaction conditions, Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst exhibits the highest CO conversion among the three Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts, so does the O2 selectivity. The onset of the CO conversion and O2 selectivity of the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst at 40 °C are 14.5% and 62.5%, respectively, while the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} catalyst exhibit a CO conversion of 3.3% and a O2 selectivity of 45.4%, and the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalyst exhibit a CO conversion of 1.9% and a O2 selectivity of 50.6%. With the rise of the reaction temperature, the CO conversion is definitely increasing while the O2 selectivity varies contrarily. This is mainly attributed to the competitive oxidation of H2, enhanced gradually, that can reduce the O2 concentration. When normalized to the Ir contents and compared under the same reaction temperature (Fig. 9C), the reaction rate of CO over the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst is always more than 2 and 8 times higher than those over the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalysts, respectively. This identifies Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} as an efficiently active catalyst in the CO-PROX reaction. These results, for the first time, report the morphology of support as a powerful strategy to tune the structures of the supported metal-oxide bi-component catalysts and their catalytic properties in heterogeneous catalysis, and further broaden the concept of morphology-dependent catalysis of oxide-based catalysts [5–7,44–46]. Afterwards, the reaction mechanism of the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts in the CO-PROX reaction was preliminarily investigated by in situ DRIFTS spectroscopy. The reaction temperature of 50 °C was chosen to ensure significant differences of both the CO conversion and the O2 selectivity. Assignments of the vibrational bands in the DRIFTS spectra of surface species were summarized in Table S5 [12,15,47–52]. As shown in Fig. 10 , similar vibrational features were observed on the various Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts during the stepwise reaction atmospheres. The Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts were first activated by 1% CO/N2 for 30 min to generate similar surface carbonaceous species, dominantly including monodentate carbonate (1500–1507 cm–1), bidentate carbonate (1550–1560 cm–1), bridged carbonate (1437–1450 cm–1), and formate (1390–1393 and 1585–1602 cm–1). Subsequently, 1% O2 was introduced in the presence of 1% CO/N2. The intensities of surface carbonaceous species gradually increase after the introduction of O2 for 30 min, indicating the occurrence of surface reaction between CO and O2. The Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} catalysts exhibit more pronounced increase of the integrated intensity than the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001} catalyst as evidenced by the normalized intensity changes of the vibrational band at ∼1440 cm–1 verse time during the CO + O2 experiments (Fig. S5), matching well with the observed generation of the oxygenate species in the O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 5A2–C2) and their CO conversions in the CO-PROX reaction (Fig. 9A). This indicates a better CO reactivity appearing over the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} and Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} catalysts. When 50% H2 was further introduced into the reaction cell to simulate the CO-PROX reaction, the integrated intensities of monodentate carbonate, bridged carbonate, and formate species decline rapidly, especially for the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst with almost complete vanishment of these surface carbonaceous species after the introduction of H2 for 3 min. It has been frequently reported the H2-assited consumption of surface carbonaceous species via a H-spillover effect over noble metal-based catalysts that can promote the production of CO2 in CO-PROX reaction [53–55]. In this regard, it is quite consistent that a stronger H-spillover effect observed on the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst leads to a faster decay of the surface carbonaceous species. Therefore, these results indicate different reaction mechanisms of CO oxidation in the presence of H2 or not. The catalytic performance of the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts in the CO-PROX reaction is not only affected by the CO reactivity, but also determined by the H-spillover effect associated with the Ir-FeOx interactions to facilitate the surface intermediates transformation into CO2. Unfortunately, it is difficult to identify which one of the surface carbonaceous species is dominantly contributive to the CO oxidation on the basis of the current results. 4 Conclusions Microscopic and spectroscopic investigations on the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts with different TiO2 morphologies have successfully demonstrated the TiO2 morphology-dependent Ir-TiO2, FeOx-TiO2 and Ir-FeOx interactions, and catalysis in the CO-PROX reaction. The strongest FeOx-TiO2 interactions were observed over the TiO2{001} support while the strongest Ir-TiO2 and Ir-FeOx interactions occurred over the TiO2{101} support. Particularly, the Ir-FeOx interactions could be qualitatively compared by the Ir particle shape in the TEM images, the percentage of the Fe2+ species in the Fe 2p XPS spectra, the percentage of the Irδ+ species in both the Ir 4f spectra and the in situ DRIFTS of CO chemisorption, and the reduction temperature of the FeOx species in the H2-TPR results, following the strength order of Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} > Ir-FeOx/TiO2{100} > Ir-FeOx/TiO2{001}. Catalytic performance of the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts in the CO-PROX reactions should be associated with the Ir-FeOx interfaces that is determined by the Ir-FeOx interactions. The best catalytic performance on the Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst for the CO-PROX reaction could be associated with the strongest Ir-FeOx interactions that are beneficial to the H-spillover effect and subsequently facilitate the transformation of surface carbonaceous intermediates into CO2. This work not only deepens the fundamental understanding of the Ir-FeOx interfaces in the CO-PROX reaction, but also demonstrates the morphology engineering of oxide supports as a powerful strategy to achieve structural design and controlled synthesis of novel efficient oxide-based catalysts CRediT authorship contribution statement Yang Wen: Methodology. coredata.dc:description: Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts with both Ir and Fe contents of ∼1% wt. employing anatase TiO2 nanocrystals predominantly exposing either {100}, {101}, or {001} facets as the support were prepared and a comprehensive study was conducted on their interactions in pairs that are strongly dependent on the TiO2 morphology. The strongest FeOx-TiO2 interactions occurred over TiO2{001} support while TiO2{101} support contributes to the strongest Ir-TiO2 and Ir-FeOx interactions. Catalytic performance of the Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts in preferential oxidation of CO in H2 is not only affected by the CO reactivity, but also determined by the Ir-FeOx interfaces. Ir-FeOx/TiO2{101} catalyst exhibits the highest CO conversion and best O2 selectivity over the three Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts, which could be ascribed to stronger Ir-FeOx interactions that contribute to the enhancement of a H-spillover effect and subsequently facilitate the transformation of surface carbonaceous intermediates into CO2. These results add the versatility of the morphology engineering strategy in tailoring the structures and catalytic performance of oxide-based catalysts, and broaden the concept of morphology-dependent catalysis of oxide-based nanocrystal catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Tailoring Ir-FeOx interactions and catalytic performance in preferential oxidation of CO in H2 via the morphology engineering of anatase TiO2 over Ir-FeOx/TiO2 catalysts
